thread.title: Asia stocks off record highs as Wall Street flags, higher yields support dollar

title: Asia stocks off record highs as Wall Street flags, higher yields support dollar
text:
January 30, 2018 / 12:38 AM / Updated 44 minutes ago Global stocks tumble anew amid bond yield pressure Herbert Lash 5 Min Read 
NEW YORK (Reuters) - World stocks declined in their biggest two-day dive in almost six months on Tuesday as tumbling oil prices and a jump in global borrowing costs cooled the year’s euphoric start in financial markets. 
Lackluster German inflation curbed a rise in U.S. Treasury yields - the benchmark for world lending rates - after they touched their strongest level in nearly four years overnight at 2.733 percent. 
Stocks on Wall Street shed around 1 percent, led by a plunge in healthcare-related companies after Amazon.com ( AMZN.O ), Berkshire Hathaway ( BRKa.N ) and JPMorgan ( JPM.N ) said they plan to form a venture to cut healthcare costs for their U.S. employees. 
Healthcare .SPXHC tumbled 2.06 percent, the biggest decline among the 11 major S&P 500 sectors. 
Health insurer UnitedHealth ( UNH.N ) and drugmaker Pfizer ( PFE.N ) were among the top five decliners in the S&P 500, falling 4.05 percent and 3.66 percent, respectively. 
Pfizer had risen about 2 percent in pre-market trading after the company’s quarterly results and full-year forecasts beat expectations. 
Stocks were also pulled lower by a decline in energy shares amid ongoing evidence of rising U.S. crude output. 
The S&P energy sector .SPNY fell 1.85 percent. 
Investors were spooked by the two-day decline on Wall Street, which prompted a flight to the safety of U.S. government bonds, said Gennadiy Goldberg, interest rates strategist at TD Securities in New York. 
Investors awaited President Donald Trump’s first State of the Union address to Congress Tuesday night, a Federal Reserve statement on Wednesday and a jobs report on Friday that serves as a key barometer of the U.S. economy. 
The Fed will be watched for comments that could quicken the pace of expected interest rate hikes this year as the inflation outlook has firmed in recent readings. 
“Investors are getting a bit worried about inflation, which has led some people to believe that the Fed might be more aggressive when it comes to raising rates,” said Robert Pavlik, chief investment strategist at SlateStone Wealth. 
“Despite this selloff, all indications point to a firming economy and I do expect to see some bargain hunters step in soon,” Pavlik said. 
On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average .DJI fell 374.55 points, or 1.42 percent, to 26,064.93. The S&P 500 .SPX lost 30.64 points, or 1.07 percent, to 2,822.89 and the Nasdaq Composite .IXIC dropped 72.40 points, or 0.97 percent, to 7,394.10. 
The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index .FTEU3 closed down 0.83 percent and MSCI's gauge of stock performance in 47 countries around the globe .MIWD PUS shed 0.95 percent. 
Benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury notes US10YT=RR fell 4/32 in price to yield 2.7142 percent. 
Germany’s 10-year bond DE10YT=RR fell to 0.68 percent, down about 1 basis point on the day. After going positive for the first time since late 2015 on Monday, five-year German bond DE5YT=RR yields slipped back into negative territory. 
The dollar reversed Monday’s gains. After six straight weekly declines, the dollar index was on track to fall about 3.4 percent for the month, which would be its biggest monthly fall since March 2016. 
The dollar index .DXY fell 0.15 percent, with the euro EUR= up 0.16 percent to $1.2401. The Japanese yen strengthened 0.17 percent versus the greenback at 108.79 per dollar JPY= . 
Brent crude futures LCOc1 settled down 44 cents to $69.02 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate futures CLc1 slid $1.06 to settle at $64.50. 
Expectations for U.S. crude inventories to rise   11 weeks may also be keeping oil under pressure, according to a preliminary poll by Reuters on Monday. [EIA/S]USOILC=ECI 
“The global trend seems to be indicating more oil is coming into the market despite best efforts by the Saudis and Russians to curtail output,” said John Kilduff, partner at Again Capital LLC in New York. 
Gold slipped back to a one-week low. 
U.S. gold futures GCcv1 for February delivery settled down $4.90 at $1,335.40 per ounce. Reporting by Herbert Lash; Editing by Nick Zieminski and James Dalgleish
